Ask HN: What would you work on if you had 100 devs
text:
I was wondering after the discussion of Googles crazy hiring, If you just had such a number of developers that you then had to find a reason to justify within a year or two, what would you work on? Would your perceived quality of these developers impact what you aimed for, and what would you do to assess their quality?

Maybe the question is a bit broad but if you have a direction you're interested in taking this what-if, please run with it.

Tell HN: Google has removed the option to disable Discover on Android update
text:
It seems that Google don't want you to disable Google Discover anymore.

If you are not familiar, Google Discover is accessed by swiping left on the main screen of your Android phone. It is a compilation of the most trash and useless piece of "news" that you can possible imagine: "Celebrities" gossip and AD's presented as articles [2].

As you can see of figure [1], the option to disable Google Discover is missing on the update. First screen is my phone (old android version) second screen is my tablet (new android version) with the option gone.

Why do they insist in pushing trash down their users throat?

After looking for 30 minutes on how to disable swipe left to Google Discover, the solution I end up adopting was to buy a new Launcher.

Talk about shitty dark patterns.

1 - https://imgur.com/a/FEfjNrW

2 - https://imgur.com/a/3sCkfGy

title: Leaving SRE for development job. Am I crazy?
text:
My career path started in Ops, which evolved into SRE. I never did any formal training of any kind really. I'm entirely self taught. I feel confident in my skillset for the most part but I wonder if taking a backend/api development job might help me understand the world that I happen to find myself in a little more deeply. I've never had a dedicated development job so I don't think I really even understand what I'm missing by not doing it.

Has anyone else done this?

Also, it seems like developer jobs in general don't pay as well as SRE. Anyone have any thoughts on how can I weigh the value of the experience vs the lost wages?
